name: Damodar River
description: Flows from Palamu hills and known as the 'Sorrow of Bengal'.
culturalOverview: The Damodar River is historically significant for Bengal and Jharkhand, associated with legends, floods, and coal belt prosperity.
importance: Supports agriculture and industrial needs across Jharkhand and West Bengal.

name: Subarnarekha River
description: Originates in Chhotanagpur Plateau; named 'Golden Line', passes in Ranchi, Jamshedpur.
culturalOverview: It holds mythological links to gold discoveries and has nourished civilizations along its banks.
importance: Important for water supply in Ranchi and Jamshedpur.

name: Sankh River
description: Rises in Chhotanagpur Plateau and merges with Koel; scenic river with local significance.
culturalOverview: Known in tribal traditions and songs, the Sankh River reflects the cultural identity of the plateau region.
importance: Joins the South Koel River to form the Brahmani, crucial for agriculture and water management.

name: Koel River
description: Flows from Ranchi Plateau; major tributary of Brahmani River supporting agriculture.
culturalOverview: The Koel River is admired in tribal songs and folklore, enriching the local culture.
importance: Vital for irrigation and hydropower projects.

name: Mayurakshi River
description: Starts from Trikut hills; its serene course makes it ideal for riverside relaxation.
culturalOverview: The river is linked with spiritual and cultural practices, adding to its sanctity.
importance: Provides irrigation and supports fishing communities in its basin.

name: Ajay River
description: Flows through Jharkhand into West Bengal; supports local irrigation and communities.
culturalOverview: Mentioned in regional folklore, the Ajay River shaped settlements along its banks.
importance: Essential for irrigation, agriculture, and local livelihood support.

name: Barakar River
description: Originates from Chhotanagpur Plateau; joins Damodar River and aids coal transport.
culturalOverview: Closely tied with the Damodar Valley and mining history of Jharkhand.
importance: Major tributary of Damodar; vital for coal transportation and industrial water use.

name: Brahmani River
description: Formed by South Koel and Sankh rivers; important for agriculture and industry.
culturalOverview: Considered sacred in parts of eastern India, sustaining traditions and cultural practices.
importance: Supports agriculture, industries, and hydroelectric projects across Jharkhand and Odisha.
